meta_data.title: Sometimes Scribes Scribe Things in the Bible

transcription_data.text: the you ever see the thing in a movie where you got an important person but the important person the leader good guy bad guy doesn't matter they've got sidekick and the sidekick is sort of their mouthpiece they're the spokesperson maybe they got a bullhorn or something and throughout the movie sidekick mouthpiece guy gives all these speeches on behalf of the leader but then at some point the leader is like you're not no I need to say this part gimme gimme that and I'll take the bullhorn or the microphone and then they're like attention it is I so and so talking now listen very closely this is important I have seen that happen a lot of times and I find it to be a very relatable moment where it would make sense that with all the busyness of an important good guy leader or an important bad guy leader you wouldn't have time to focus on all of the exact syntax and speech writing stuff you got to be working on the ideas and other things and it would make sense you would have somebody who would play that role as a part of your team but then it would also make sense that from time to time you'd be like now this is too important or they just need to know that this is for sure coming from me and not my sidekick they need to know that there's no intermediary here this is me talking I want to put all my weight and all of my authority behind it so attention please I'm talking now well I think we're getting one of those kind of sequences here at the very end of the book of Galatians most of the letters it looks like in the New Testament were not penned by the people who are signing the letters they were actually inked and written down by sort of a human printer sort of a human word processor and for all of our lives you and I we've had a device that does this for us a typewriter a word processor a computer heck AI does the writing for some people I'm not into that but I know some people do it and we've all had some sort of mechanical assistant that does this for us well back in the day there was still a demand to process words is just that had to be done by a human with a brain who is trained for it we called them scribes and in Galatians 611 Paul is acknowledging I am using a scribe in this letter well in so many words he is because he effectively yanks the bullhorn away from his faithful assistant who seems to have died a very lovely job I've read the whole book several times it's very very good excellent even but he still Paul is like I want my authority to come through here I want people to know this is from me so Paul metaphorically grabs the metaphorical bullhorn from the not metaphorical sidekick and is like attention please please please this is Paul Paul himself self self ccc what large letters undersolders I use as I write right right to you with my own hand hand hand and so of course the interpretive cue for you and me is that we should look really closely at whatever he says next and oh trust me my friend we're gonna right after we think more about the implications of the fact that Paul has somebody else writing his letters is that weird now you might be thinking okay well no I've heard about this before you've mentioned it a few times that this is a new testament practice but it's actually a practice that we see in the Old Testament as well in fact there is a very important character in a gigantic book of the Old Testament who is in the plot he's a part of things he's a part of all the messes and crazy misadventures and dangerous stuff that happens to the named character of the book and the scribe of the book the assistant of the book he not only helped write the thing but he features very prominently in the story as well and the book I'm talking about is how many of century gap he's getting started in his career probably at the very end of the six hundreds and then of course Jeremiah he's the one whose prophecies nobody likes because his prophecy is we blew it God is sending judgment in the form of Babylon it's coming I'm just gonna tell you in advance here's how you're gonna need to live when you get taken into exile and so you know Jeremiah is not well liked and there's a ton of narrative in Jeremiah that people kind of forget is there until you go back and look at it but my point is here we are 600 ish years before the time of the New Testament letters and we see the practice of having a secretary or a scribe being closely involved with what's going on with a prophet of God we see that practice in place and Baruch he's not a sidekick he comes off like a a deputy prophet who has authority and is doing the legit official stuff here so then the question becomes okay well what about the New Testament what about these guys who are writing
